questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of recurring black stools. He also reports fatigue and loss of appetite over the last 3 months. Twenty years ago, he underwent a partial gastrectomy for peptic ulcer disease. The patient's father died of metastatic colon cancer at the age of 57 years. He is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. He appears chronically ill. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. The conjunctiva appear pale. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a well-healed scar on the upper abdomen. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL and his mean corpuscular volume is 101 μm3. An upper endoscopy shows a large nodular mass on the anterior wall of the lesser curvature of the gastric stump. Biopsy samples are obtained, showing polypoid, glandular formation of irregular-shaped and fused gastric cells with intraluminal mucus, demonstrating an infiltrative growth. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stool antigen test for Helicobacter pylori
Treatment with PPI, bismuth, tetracycline, and metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with a 3–6 fold increase in the risk of gastric cancer, the prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with gastric adenocarcinoma is less than 1 in 1000. Moreover, diagnosing an H. pylori infection would not alter the diagnostic or therapeutic approach in a patient with a gastric adenocarcinoma that has already been confirmed via biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

A staging laparoscopy may be indicated for patients with locally advanced gastric tumors without evidence of lymph node spread or distant metastasis on preoperative imaging to assess whether the tumor is resectable. If the tumor is resectable, diagnostic staging laparoscopy may be directly followed by gastrectomy to avoid the need for undergoing anesthesia again. However, an additional diagnostic test must first be performed to look for evidence of lymph node spread or distant metastasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Optimized bismuth quadruple therapy is used to eradicate Helicobacter pylori. Although H. pylori infection causes a 3–6 fold increase in the risk of gastric cancer, the prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with gastric carcinoma is less than 1 in 1000. Routine H. pylori eradication therapy is not recommended in patients with gastric adenocarcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

An abdominopelvic CT scan is necessary to identify anatomic spread to the lymph nodes (i.e., those along the lesser and greater curvature as well as celiac, paraaortic, and mesenteric lymph nodes), and adjacent organs (e.g., liver, diaphragm, pancreas) to correctly stage gastric carcinoma. When first diagnosed with stomach cancer, about 70% of patients already show metastatic spread to the lymph nodes.

As a part of staging, a chest CT should also be performed to search for pulmonary metastases. Additionally, an endosonography, usually performed at the time of endoscopy, may be useful to determine the depth of the tumor invasion.

E) INCORRECT:

Barium upper GI series are only used for the initial diagnosis of gastric cancer in patients with obstructive symptoms (e.g., dysphagia) or those with proximal gastric tumors that prevent the passage of the endoscope. This patient does not present with dysphagia, and endoscopy has already been performed to confirm gastric cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated TNF-alpha levels are common in patients with gastric cancer and may even be associated with better postoperative outcomes and higher 5-year survival rates. However, current diagnostic guidelines do not recommend the routine assessment of TNF-alpha. A different diagnostic test is required to assess the stage of the tumor and the degree of tumor spread before surgical treatment can be considered.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient has pale conjunctiva and fatigue that is likely associated with macrocytic anemia, as indicated by his low hemoglobin and high mean corpuscular volume. Ten to forty percent of patients who undergo partial gastrectomy, and nearly all patients who undergo total gastrectomy, will eventually develop vitamin B12 deficiency as a result of intrinsic factor deficiency if vitamin B12 supplementation is not provided. While longstanding vitamin B12 deficiency may explain this patient's anemia, tests to diagnose vitamin B12 deficiency are not as urgently required as other diagnostic tests that could assess the spread of gastric cancer.
questions.hint: Gastrectomy can result in achlorhydria, overgrowth of nitrite-producing bacteria, and reflux of bile through the gastrojejunal anastomosis, all of which increase the risk of gastric cancer. This patient's fatigue, loss of appetite, and melena, in combination with his biopsy findings, suggest gastric adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of diarrhea and weakness after her meals for 2 weeks. She has the urge to defecate 15–20 minutes after a meal and has 3–6 bowel movements a day. She also has palpitations, sweating, and needs to lie down soon after eating. One month ago, she underwent a distal gastrectomy for gastric cancer. She had post-operative pneumonia, which was treated with cefotaxime. She returned from a vacation to Brazil 6 weeks ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a well-healed abdominal midline surgical scar. The abdomen is soft and nontender; bowel sounds are hyperactive. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reconstructive surgery (e.g., roux-en-Y reconstruction) is a late option for the treatment of dumping syndromes refractory to conservative and medical management. Surgery is intended to delay gastric emptying into the small intestine. It is rarely indicated in early dumping syndrome because it frequently resolves spontaneously. This patient has not yet been treated with conservative measures and should not be exposed to the risks of another operation.
Image Description:

Subtotal gastrectomy:
- Subtotal gastrectomy involves the resection of the body and pyloric channel of the stomach (transparent portion of the stomach in this image).
- The cardia and fundus of the stomach and their blood supply is preserved (opaque portion of the stomach here).
- The duodenal stump (dashed red line) is closed.

Roux-en-Y anastomosis:
- A segment of the proximal jejunum is divided.
- Gastrojejunostomy creation: The distal cut end of the jejunal loop (black I) is anastomosed side-to-side to the gastric stump (purple dashed line; I–I).
- Jejunojejunostomy creation: The proximal jejunal stump (green II) is anastomosed end-to-side to a distal jejunal loop (green dashed line, II–II).

B) INCORRECT:

Stool microscopy helps to diagnose parasitic infection, which is a potential cause of diarrhea, particularly in patients returning from travels abroad, as is the case here. However, the strong association of this patient's symptoms with mealtimes, her history of gastrectomy, and her normal vital signs suggest another underlying diagnosis for her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Stool PCR is used in the detection of several microorganisms commonly responsible for infectious diarrhea, including Clostridium difficile. Infection is a common cause of diarrhea, particularly in those returning from travels, as is the case here. Also, this patient has healthcare exposures and has been treated with antibiotics; both are known risk factors for C. difficile infection. However, the association of this patient's symptoms with mealtimes, her history of gastrectomy, and her normal vital signs make infection unlikely. In addition, C. difficile infection typically occurs during antibiotic treatment or soon (i.e., within 5–10 days) after antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is used to reduce intestinal motility and delay gastric emptying, which can be helpful in severe cases of dumping and post-vagotomy syndromes. Octreotide also inhibits the release of insulin, thereby reducing symptoms in patients with late dumping syndrome. In general, most cases of dumping syndrome respond to conservative management, which this patient has not yet attempted.

E) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is an antibiotic used to treat diarrhea caused by anaerobes (such as mild to moderate Clostridium difficile infection) and protozoa. Infection is less likely in this patient given the association of her symptoms with mealtimes, her history of gastrectomy, and her normal vital signs.

F) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of early dumping syndrome is primarily clinical, and dietary modifications are the initial treatment of choice. In early dumping syndrome, large amounts of carbohydrate-rich food are emptied rapidly into the small intestine, causing fluid shifts and sympathetic activation. To prevent this, initial treatment involves frequent, small, low-carbohydrate meals to reduce the osmotic load on the small intestine. Other behavioral modifications (e.g., 30–60 min of supine rest) may also be helpful. Symptoms of early dumping syndrome are usually self-limiting and resolve after a few months. Dumping syndrome that is not adequately controlled with dietary modification can be treated with octreotide.
questions.hint: Diarrhea, urge to defecate, weakness, and vasomotor symptoms (sweating, palpitations) soon after eating in someone who has undergone a distal gastrectomy suggest early dumping syndrome.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of abdominal bloating, early satiety, and multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting of undigested food. Today, the patient had two episodes of dark brown vomiting. He has also had severe episodic epigastric pain and heartburn for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food and over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Serum studies show:


Na+

135 mEq/L


K+

3.3 mEq/L


Cl-

93 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
46 mg/dL


Glucose
77 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

GOO can be caused by acute or chronic peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This patient has had episodic epigastric pain and heartburn for only one week, suggesting acute PUD, which can cause obstruction via inflammation-induced edema and tissue deformation of the gastroduodenal junction. In patients with chronic PUD, which is most commonly seen in individuals with long-term NSAID use or those with Helicobacter pylori infection, GOO can result from scarring and tissue fibrosis. Other causes of GOO include malignancy (most common) and strictures in the pyloric channel (e.g., due to Crohn disease, ingestion of a caustic substance, or chronic pancreatitis).

In patients with GOO, persistent vomiting can lead to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis and decreased fluid uptake, the latter of which can result in prerenal acute kidney injury evidenced in this patient by elevated serum urea nitrogen and creatinine. In cases of suspected GOO, upper endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. Initial management includes nasogastric suction, electrolyte and fluid replacement, and parenteral nutrition. Further treatment should target the underlying cause (e.g., proton pump inhibitor therapy in patients with PUD). If conservative measures fail, endoscopic dilation or surgery can be considered for definitive treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the aortomesenteric angle, also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA syndrome), is a cause of proximal small bowel obstruction, which may present with postprandial vomiting and epigastric pain immediately after meals. Risk factors include surgery, severe and rapid weight loss, prolonged bed rest, or rapid growth. Although this patient has acute symptoms of vomiting and epigastric pain, his pain occurs at night several hours after eating and does not have any of the other risk factors. In addition, SMA syndrome is usually not associated with gastrointestinal bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Abnormal gastric rotation (gastric volvulus) may result in GOO. Mild gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur due to ulceration of gastric mucosa in a malrotated stomach. However, gastric volvulus is a rare cause of GOO and typically affects individuals over the age of 50 years. Individuals with gastric volvulus typically also have retching without vomiting.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, such as pancreatic adenocarcinoma with duodenal or gastric extension or distal gastric cancer, are a common cause of GOO. This patient is at increased risk of malignancy given his family history of a first-degree relative with colon cancer and personal history of smoking and alcohol use. However, his acute onset of symptoms, young age, and episodes of epigastric pain several hours after eating are more consistent with a different underlying condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is most often associated with longstanding H. pylori-induced chronic gastritis and chronic NSAID use. Chronic PUD can cause GOO due to scarring and tissue remodeling as a part of the healing process from long-term injury, eventually causing obstruction of the gastroduodenal junction. However, this patient has only had 1 week of symptoms, suggesting that his PUD is acute rather than chronic.

F) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic pseudocysts are walled-off pancreatic fluid collections that can cause symptoms of GOO. Although pancreatic pseudocysts may manifest with abdominal tenderness, an abdominal mass, and indigestion, they are almost always associated with a history of pancreatitis, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

In chronic pancreatitis, inflammation and fibrosis of pancreatic tissue can manifest with abdominal pain (main symptom), which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Symptoms of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., steatorrhea, weight loss) and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency (pancreatic diabetes) typically occur late when more than 90% of pancreatic tissue is destroyed.
questions.hint: The combination of epigastric tenderness, bloating, early satiety, persistent nonbilious emesis, gastric dilation (tympanitic epigastric mass), and a succussion splash on abdominal auscultation should raise concern for gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). This patient's heartburn, severe episodic epigastric pain that is relieved with food but worsens hours after eating, and features of gastrointestinal bleeding (positive fecal occult blood test, hematemesis) suggest a duodenal ulcer as the most likely underlying cause of GOO.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of persistent vomiting after meals. The vomitus consists of undigested food and a clear fluid. His last attempt to eat was 6 hours ago and his last bowel movement was 3 days ago. For the past 3 weeks, the patient has had worsening nausea and early satiety. He also reports a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. He has hypercholesterolemia treated with atorvastatin. The patient drinks 2–3 glasses of wine daily. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min and blood pressure is 120/65 mm Hg. Examination shows dry oral mucosa and conjunctival pallor. Abdominal examination shows epigastric fullness with mild tenderness. A sloshing sound is heard upon auscultation of the epigastrium when rocking the patient back and forth. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is helpful in diagnosing esophageal dysmotility disorders (e.g., achalasia, diffuse esophageal spasms), which can manifest with regurgitation and weight loss. However, symptom onset is typically more insidious, and a succussion splash would not be expected because the level of the obstruction is proximal to the stomach.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring can be used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients with a prolonged history of uncontrolled GERD are at increased risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma, which can lead to obstruction. However, this obstruction would lie proximal to the stomach and would therefore not cause GOO. Esophageal pH monitoring would not be an appropriate test for the diagnosis of GOO.

C) INCORRECT:

An abdominal ultrasound can be used in the diagnosis of gallbladder pathology (e.g., cholecystitis, cholelithiasis). It is also used as an initial screening test for structural abdominal masses such as a malignant tumor; however, an abdominal ultrasound is not a confirmatory diagnostic test. This patient's presentation is concerning for GOO caused by a malignant obstruction, which cannot be confirmed by abdominal ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Fecal elastase measurement can be used to evaluate for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency as seen in chronic pancreatitis. Although this patient's alcohol use, weight loss, and nausea are concerning for chronic pancreatitis, he lacks other commonly associated symptoms, e.g., chronic abdominal pain and steatorrhea.

E) CORRECT:

An upper endoscopy and an abdominal CT scan can both be used to confirm the diagnosis of structural GOO. Because this patient's age, weight loss, and alcohol use are concerning for gastric cancer, upper endoscopy is the diagnostic test of choice. In cases of suspected malignant GOO, endoscopic evaluation with a biopsy is required to obtain a histological diagnosis. Endoscopy can also provide short-term treatment with stent placement or dilation.

Until the late 1970s, most cases of GOO were caused by peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The declining prevalence of H. pylori infection and the efficacy of proton pump inhibitors in the treatment of PUD have significantly decreased the incidence of GOO due to PUD. Most cases of GOO are caused by gastric or duodenal cancer, or by extrinsic compression from enlarged lymph nodes (e.g., lymphoma) or a malignancy (i.e., pancreatic, biliary).

F) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is used to test for suspected acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). AMI manifests with acute onset, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and, in later stages, hematochezia. AMI is often described as “pain out of proportion to the physical exam.” Although this patient's history of hypercholesterolemia is a risk factor for AMI, his clinical presentation is inconsistent; he has progressive vomiting without significant abdominal pain, and he has obstipation as opposed to diarrhea.
questions.hint: This man has nonbilious emesis following food intake, early satiety, weight loss, epigastric tenderness, and a succussion splash, all of which indicate gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). In adults, GOO is caused by a malignant obstruction in the majority of cases.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and sensation of early satiety. He has also had a 9.4-kg (21-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Medical history is remarkable for osteoarthritis. His only medication is ibuprofen. He immigrated to the USA from Taiwan 10 years ago. His brother has a history of ulcerative colitis. He drinks one to two beers every night with dinner. He rarely cooks and eats all his meals at the local diner. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (134 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an ulcerated mass with raised irregular edges in the body of the stomach at the lesser curvature. A biopsy specimen of the mass obtained during endoscopy shows tubular structures with intraluminal mucus and debris and no lymphocytic infiltration. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given this patient's positive family history of ulcerative colitis, he is at risk of developing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which is an important risk factor for colorectal cancer. However, his presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with gastric adenocarcinoma, which is not associated with IBD.

B) INCORRECT:

Despite the association between peptic ulcer disease and the chronic use of NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen), NSAID use is associated with an overall decreased, not increased, risk of intestinal-type gastric cancer. NSAIDs are thought to have an inhibitory effect on carcinogenesis because of their antiproliferative and antiinflammatory action.

C) INCORRECT:

A low-fiber diet is a significant risk factor for colorectal cancers, but it is only a minor risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. A different dietary factor is a much more significant contributor to the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is a risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma and a certain histological type of gastric cancer. EBV-associated gastric cancer typically occurs in young individuals, are located at the gastric cardia, and are associated with significant lymphocyte infiltration and a diffuse-type gastric carcinoma histology. This patient has a localized gastric adenocarcinoma in the body of the stomach with minimal lymphocyte infiltration. A different factor was more likely to have resulted in gastric adenocarcinoma in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Dietary nitrates are converted to nitrites by oral commensals, and if the diet is low in antioxidants, these nitrites can be converted in the acidic, protein-rich environment of the stomach to nitrosamine compounds (e.g., dimethylnitrosamine), most of which are highly carcinogenic. Green leafy vegetables, which contain high levels of nitrates as well as antioxidants, do not increase the risk of gastric cancer. However, increased consumption of smoked, dried, fried, and preserved foods (especially meat), which contain low levels of antioxidants and high levels of nitrates, nitrites, and nitrosamines, is a significant risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma. Smoked food is a common part of the diet in East Asia, and individuals from this region have an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Other important risk factors for localized gastric adenocarcinoma include tobacco smoking, alcohol consumption, obesity, and infection with Helicobacter pylori.

F) INCORRECT:

Studies have shown that individuals with blood type A are at increased risk for both gastric cancer and Helicobacter pylori infection. However, no significant association between blood type O and gastric cancer has been demonstrated.
questions.hint: This patient with dyspepsia, early satiety, and weight loss, most likely has gastric cancer. The endoscopy and biopsy findings indicate a localized gastric adenocarcinoma (intestinal-type gastric cancer).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of epigastric pain and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss. He feels full and bloated even after eating small portions of food. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL with a mean corpuscular volume of 78 μm3. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows a 2-cm raised lesion with central ulceration on the lesser curvature of the stomach. Histologic examination of a gastric biopsy specimen from the lesion is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutrophilic infiltration with pit abscesses is seen in H. pylori-positive gastritis, which can also cause epigastric pain and is an important risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. However, the EGD findings in this patient are not consistent with gastritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Foveolar cell and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia would be consistent with chemical gastropathy, which is also characterized histologically by edema of the lamina propria. While chemical gastropathy may result in epigastric pain similar to what is seen in this patient, the degree of weight loss and the presence of a suspicious ulceration in this patient makes this diagnosis highly unlikely. Moreover, this patient has no history of risk factors for this condition, such as chronic NSAID, alcohol, or tobacco use.

C) CORRECT:

Gland-forming columnar cells are seen in adenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of gastric cancer (accounting for approx. 90% of cases). The endoscopic finding of a suspicious ulcer confined to the lesser curvature is consistent with intestinal (type I) gastric adenocarcinoma, which is characterized by aggressive local spread and typically metastasizes to the liver and regional lymph nodes. Risk factors include chronic H. pylori infection, smoking, and chronic gastritis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of gastric tissue from a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are atypical cells forming glandular structures (green circles) of various sizes with intraluminal debris.

These findings are consistent with gastric adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Noncaseating granulomas with lymphocytic aggregates are characteristic of Crohn disease, which can present with weight loss and epigastric pain similar to this patient. However, Crohn disease typically presents with chronic diarrhea and this patient lacks any characteristic extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., sacroiliitis, pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum). His endoscopy findings are more consistent with gastric adenocarcinoma, which would appear differently on histologic examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Mucin-filled round cells with a peripherally dislocated nucleus are known as signet ring cells, which would suggest signet ring cell carcinoma. A patient with this type of cancer could also present with weight loss, epigastric pain, and bloody stool. However, endoscopic examination would typically reveal diffuse involvement of the stomach wall and possibly linitis plastica, rather than a single ulceration confined to the lesser curvature.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of gastric tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

Multiple signet-ring cells (round cells filled with mucin with a flat nucleus in the cell periphery; examples indicated by green overlay) can be seen.

This finding is diagnostic of signet-ring-cell carcinoma of the stomach.
questions.hint: Epigastric pain, weight loss, early satiety, and microcytic anemia in a patient with a suspicious lesion in the lesser curvature of the stomach should raise suspicion for gastric cancer. Adenocarcinoma is by far the most common type of gastric cancer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of dull lower abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic ultrasonography shows bilateral ovarian enlargement and free fluid in the rectouterine pouch. Biopsy specimens from the ovaries show multiple, round, mucin-filled cells with flat, peripheral nuclei. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased TSH levels in association with an ovarian mass, weight loss, and pelvic pain are seen in patients with struma ovarii. However, this condition typically manifests with only unilateral involvement. Additionally, biopsy would show thyroid tissue, which is not seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased testosterone levels in association with abnormal ovaries could indicate polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or Sertoli-Leydig tumors. PCOS can manifest with bilateral ovarian enlargement, obesity, and signs of hyperandrogenism such as acne, hirsutism, and menstrual irregularities. Pelvic ultrasonography would show enlarged ovaries with numerous anechoic cysts. Sertoli-Leydig tumors also lead to clinically apparent virilization with hirsutism and acne. Biopsy shows tubules lined by round Sertoli cells and interspersed Leydig cells, both in a fibrous stroma. Neither of these diagnoses fit with these historical elements and objective findings.
Image Description:

Macroscopic specimen of an ovary, transverse section: There are multiple, circularly arranged, brown subcapsular cysts (examples indicated by green overlay) on the subcapsular region, which are relatively small and of approx. the same size. This is the typical appearance of a polycystic ovary (see illustration for a schematic representation). In addition to the abnormal changes observed here, the ovary is frequently enlarged and as a result there is an increase in stromal tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Pleural effusion, in the setting of an ovarian mass, raises concern for Meigs syndrome. Caused most often by an ovarian fibroma, this condition also classically leads to abdominal ascites. Krukenburg tumors may rarely lead to pleural effusion as well, but this would not be the most likely finding on further evaluation of this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dark blue peritoneal spots seen in endometriosis are known as powder-burn or gunshot lesions. Endometriosis can present with bilateral ovarian enlargement and abdominal pain. Histologically, this condition appears as endometrial glands in normal endometrial stroma but with a preponderance of hemosiderin-laden macrophages as a result of chronic, cyclic hemorrhages into endometriomas. This patient's weight loss and pathology findings are not consistent with endometriosis.
Image Description:

A large bisected ovarian cyst

The cyst is filled with coagulated blood from endometriosis, giving it a chocolate-like appearance.

E) CORRECT:

A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy comprised of signet ring cells that has metastasized from a primary site, most commonly the stomach. Signet ring cell carcinoma of the stomach leads to a grossly thickened and leathery stomach wall and is therefore also called linitis plastica (diffuse gastric carcinoma). The history of decreased appetite and substantial weight loss is explained by the primary malignant tumor. Metastases are typically found in both ovaries and often occur in conjunction with ascites, as seen in this patient.

Though the diffuse type of gastric carcinoma is the most common type of gastric cancer to metastasize to the ovaries, other types of gastric cancer, as well as breast cancer, endometrial cancer, and colon cancer, can also cause Krukenberg tumor.
Image Description:

Ovarian resection specimen

The ovary appears diffusely enlarged and has a smooth surface. The heterogeneous tissue contains streaks of cystic, mucoid tissue.

Krukenberg tumors are usually secondary to gastric signet ring cell carcinoma or breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels are implicated in the development of theca lutein cysts. These typically are diagnosed in pregnancy and arise in the bilateral ovaries. Although many cases are asymptomatic, episodic peritoneal irritation as a result of cyst rupture can occur. Notable weight loss would be unlikely and histopathology would show hyperplasia of the theca interna cells but not round, mucin-filled cells as in this patient's biopsy.
questions.hint: This woman has bilateral ovarian masses that contain signet ring cells (round, mucin-filled cells with a flat, peripheral nucleus), which indicates a diagnosis of Krukenberg tumor.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue. During this time, he also has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss, which he attributes to poor appetite. He has not noticed any changes in his bowel movements or urination. He has hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. A colonoscopy 3 years ago and a CT scan of the chest 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 42 years. He is 174 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. There are firm palpable nodules in his left supraclavicular and periumbilical areas. Chest auscultation discloses no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following studies is most likely to establish a diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear (PBS) can detect abnormal WBCs (e.g., blast cells, smudge cells) and has diagnostic value in patients suspected to have leukemia, which can manifest with lymphadenopathy (in lymphoid leukemias), anemia, and constitutional symptoms. However, the characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with a different type of malignancy, which cannot be diagnosed by PBS because it would most likely be normal or only show microcytes (since the anemia in this type of malignancy is caused by chronic blood loss and iron deficiency).

B) INCORRECT:

Prostate-specific antigen testing is performed as the first step in the diagnosis of prostate cancer, which is the most common malignancy in elderly men. However, spread to both the supraclavicular and periumbilical lymph nodes is an extremely rare initial manifestation of metastatic prostate cancer; this pattern of lymph node metastases is more consistent with a different type of malignancy.

C) CORRECT:

Palpable nodes in both the left supraclavicular region (Virchow nodes) and periumbilical area (Sister Mary Joseph node) are highly characteristic of metastatic gastric cancer. The diagnosis of gastric cancer is established by visualizing the primary tumor and obtaining a biopsy specimen during upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Since most individuals with gastric cancer are initially asymptomatic or have nonspecific findings such as epigastric discomfort, nausea, weight loss, or anemia, this malignancy is usually diagnosed during later stages when metastatic spread and/or symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction become apparent.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymph node biopsy (LNB) is used to diagnose lymphoma, which can manifest with constitutional symptoms, multiple noncontiguous enlarged lymph nodes (in non-Hodgkin lymphoma), and, in advanced disease, with anemia. However, the characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with a different type of malignancy, which cannot be diagnosed by LNB because it can only reveal the malignancy's histology but not its primary location.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest with contrast is the preferred initial step in the diagnosis of primary lung cancer. The characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with an extrathoracic primary tumor. In patients with this malignancy, a chest CT is performed to screen for additional intrathoracic metastases but it cannot establish the diagnosis.
questions.hint: The pattern of lymphadenopathy in this patient is highly characteristic of metastases from cancer in a particular location. The most common histological type of this malignancy is adenocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman who underwent Roux-en-Y bariatric surgery 2 months ago reports several episodes of abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, lightheadedness, and nausea, occurring about 15 minutes after eating. During one episode, her glucose level, measured with a fingerstick device, was 75 mg/dL. Since the surgery, she has lost about 30 pounds.
The patient has no history of diabetes mellitus or use of diabetic medications. Her current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, levothyroxine 100 μg daily, a multivitamin, and a vitamin D supplement.
The patient’s vital signs, physical examination, and basic laboratory tests (including complete blood count and metabolic panel) are unremarkable. Her BMI is 37.
Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Advise the patient to eat a sugary food at onset of symptoms
Advise the patient to avoid refined carbohydrates
Hospitalize the patient for a supervised fast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia is not present in early dumping syndrome; therefore, eating sugary foods at symptom onset is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Occasionally, gastric bypass patients develop a late dumping syndrome that occurs one to 3 hours after eating and is associated with hypoglycemia. If mild, this syndrome (also called noninsulinoma pancreatogenous hypoglycemia) can be treated with acarbose, but some cases necessitate reversal of the procedure or partial pancreatectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

A low-carbohydrate diet is more appropriate than a low-fat diet, given that low-fat diets often include a substantial amount of carbohydrates.

D) CORRECT:

Early dumping syndrome manifests as vasomotor symptoms (palpitations, diaphoresis, flushing, and lightheadedness) and abdominal symptoms (nausea, diarrhea, and bloating) occurring very soon after eating. It is quite common in the first week after Roux-en-Y bariatric surgery but generally resolves spontaneously within 8 to 12 weeks. The presumed cause is rapid emptying of carbohydrate from the gastric pouch into the intestine. Patients can minimize or prevent symptoms by reducing the amount of sugary foods and simple carbohydrates in their diet. A low-carbohydrate diet is more appropriate than a low-fat diet, given that low-fat diets often include a substantial amount of carbohydrates.

Key learning point: Early postprandial symptoms of nausea, diarrhea, and lightheadedness after bariatric surgery are characteristic of dumping syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

A supervised fast is appropriate for patients with suspected hypoglycemic disorder or insulinoma, which is not a diagnostic consideration in this case.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman presents with nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain. She reports nonspecific abdominal discomfort, dark stools and dark urine, and a 9.1-kg weight loss during the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals notable skin lesions (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

B) CORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers. Other paraneoplastic entities that can be associated with gastric cancer include membranous nephropathy, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, hypercoagulable states (e.g., Trousseau syndrome), polyarteritis nodosa, and diffuse seborrheic keratoses (known as the Leser-Trélat sign).

Key learning point: The type of cancer with which acanthosis nigricans is most associated is gastric cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

D) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

E) INCORRECT:

The velvety, hyperpigmented patches present in the skin folds of this patient are indicative of acanthosis nigricans, which is more commonly associated with gastric cancer than with other cancers.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension and gout has been at a rehabilitation facility for 6 months after undergoing surgery for a right hip fracture he sustained during a fall. His mobility has slowly improved with physical therapy, but he still requires significant assistance in walking and using the bathroom. During his stay at the facility, he has been weighed routinely and has unintentionally lost 8 kg, approximately 1.5 kg per month. He eats three meals per day but does not usually finish his meals. He reports feeling hungry before meals but becomes full shortly after he starts eating.
He lived alone before his fall, and when asked about his current experience, reports that he is happy and that the food is “pretty good.” He reports no heartburn, dysphagia, abdominal pain, nausea, chest pain, shortness of breath, or depression. He has a family history of coronary artery disease, and his mother had breast cancer at age 81.
His vital signs are normal except for his weight (71 kg, down from 79 kg 6 months ago). His physical examination is unremarkable except for decreased right leg length and decreased mobility of his right hip.
Laboratory testing reveals a hematocrit of 37% (reference range, 41–53), but the remainder of his complete blood count as well as his complete chemistry panel, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and C-reactive protein level are all normal.
A chest and abdominal radiograph shows degenerative disk disease but is otherwise unremarkable. He had a colonoscopy at age 75, which showed one small hyperplastic polyp in the sigmoid colon.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography is not recommended in this setting. It may be useful in staging if a malignancy is diagnosed on esophagogastroduodenoscopy, but it is not recommended as a screening tool for patients with weight loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral nutritional supplementation is recommended for older adults with weight loss. However, appetite stimulants, such as megestrol acetate and the antidepressant mirtazapine, are not generally recommended in this setting because the benefits are unclear and there may be side effects.

C) CORRECT:

An involuntary weight loss of >5% of total body weight during a 6- to 12-month period should trigger evaluation, particularly in an older adult. This patient appears to have inadequate dietary intake, which is a common cause of weight loss and can be related to social issues (such as difficulty obtaining food), psychological factors (such as depression), medical causes (such as malignancy), and the physiology of aging.

Given this patient’s reported early satiety and mild anemia, the most appropriate next step is esophagogastroduodenoscopy to evaluate for gastric cancer, peptic ulcer disease, or another gastric pathology that could be causing his symptoms. This patient is relatively healthy and a reasonable candidate for an endoscopic procedure, but the risks associated with an invasive procedure requiring sedation should always be weighed against the benefits of intervention, particularly in older adults. CT of the chest and abdomen is another reasonable option for an older patient with unexplained weight loss and no localizing symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a relatively healthy older adult with involuntary weight loss, inadequate dietary intake, early satiety, and mild anemia is esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral nutritional supplementation is recommended for older adults with weight loss. However, appetite stimulants, such as megestrol acetate and the antidepressant mirtazapine, are not generally recommended in this setting because the benefits are unclear and there may be side effects. Mirtazapine may be considered in a patient with depression and unintentional weight loss, but this patient does not have depression.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not generally recommended for older adults with unexplained weight loss in the absence of localizing symptoms. In addition, this patient appears to be up to date on colorectal cancer screening.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of persistent vomiting after meals. The vomitus consists of undigested food and a clear fluid. His last attempt to eat was 6 hours ago and his last bowel movement was 3 days ago. For the past 3 weeks, the patient has had worsening nausea and early satiety. He also reports a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. The patient drinks 2–3 glasses of wine daily. Abdominal examination shows epigastric fullness with mild tenderness. A sloshing sound is heard upon auscultation of the epigastrium when rocking the patient back and forth. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is helpful in diagnosing esophageal dysmotility disorders (e.g., achalasia, diffuse esophageal spasms), which can manifest with regurgitation and weight loss. However, symptom onset is typically more insidious, and a succussion splash would not be expected because the level of the obstruction is proximal to the stomach.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring can be used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients with a prolonged history of uncontrolled GERD are at increased risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma, which can lead to obstruction. However, this obstruction would lie proximal to the stomach and would therefore not cause GOO. Esophageal pH monitoring would not be an appropriate test for the diagnosis of GOO.

C) INCORRECT:

Fecal elastase measurement can be used to evaluate for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency as seen in chronic pancreatitis. Although this patient's alcohol use, weight loss, and nausea are concerning for chronic pancreatitis, he lacks other commonly associated symptoms, e.g., chronic abdominal pain and steatorrhea.

D) CORRECT:

An upper endoscopy and an abdominal CT scan can both be used to confirm the diagnosis of structural GOO. Because this patient's age, weight loss, and alcohol use are concerning for gastric cancer, upper endoscopy is the diagnostic test of choice. In cases of suspected malignant GOO, endoscopic evaluation with a biopsy is required to obtain a histological diagnosis. Endoscopy can also provide short-term treatment with stent placement or dilation.

Until the late 1970s, most cases of GOO were caused by peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The declining prevalence of H. pylori infection and the efficacy of proton pump inhibitors in the treatment of PUD have significantly decreased the incidence of GOO due to PUD. Most cases of GOO are caused by gastric or duodenal cancer, or by extrinsic compression from enlarged lymph nodes (e.g., lymphoma) or a malignancy (i.e., pancreatic, biliary).

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is used to test for suspected acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). AMI manifests with acute onset, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and, in later stages, hematochezia. AMI is often described as “pain out of proportion to the physical exam.” Although this patient's history of hypercholesterolemia is a risk factor for AMI, his clinical presentation is inconsistent; he has progressive vomiting without significant abdominal pain, and he has obstipation as opposed to diarrhea.
questions.hint: This man has nonbilious emesis following food intake, early satiety, weight loss, epigastric tenderness, and a succussion splash, all of which indicate gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). In adults, GOO is caused by a malignant obstruction in the majority of cases.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and sensation of early satiety. He has also had a 9.4-kg (21-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. He immigrated to the USA from Taiwan 10 years ago. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an ulcerated mass with raised irregular edges in the body of the stomach at the lesser curvature. A biopsy specimen of the mass obtained during endoscopy confirms gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is not associated with gastric adenocarcinoma. IBD is an important risk factor for colorectal cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAID use is associated with an overall decreased, not increased, risk of intestinal-type gastric cancer. NSAIDs are thought to have an inhibitory effect on carcinogenesis because of their antiproliferative and antiinflammatory action.

C) INCORRECT:

A low-fiber diet is a significant risk factor for colorectal cancers, but it is only a minor risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. A different dietary factor is a much more significant contributor to the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Dietary nitrates are converted to nitrites by oral commensals, and if the diet is low in antioxidants, these nitrites can be converted in the acidic, protein-rich environment of the stomach to nitrosamine compounds (e.g., dimethylnitrosamine), most of which are highly carcinogenic. Green leafy vegetables, which contain high levels of nitrates as well as antioxidants, do not increase the risk of gastric cancer. However, increased consumption of smoked, dried, fried, and preserved foods (especially meat), which contain low levels of antioxidants and high levels of nitrates, nitrites, and nitrosamines, is a significant risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma. Smoked food is a common part of the diet in East Asia, and individuals from this region have an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Other important risk factors for localized gastric adenocarcinoma include tobacco smoking, alcohol consumption, obesity, and infection with Helicobacter pylori.

E) INCORRECT:

Studies have shown that individuals with blood type A are at increased risk for both gastric cancer and Helicobacter pylori infection. However, no significant association between blood type O and gastric cancer has been demonstrated.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of persistent upper abdominal discomfort and unintentional weight loss of 4 kg to the Outpatient Clinic. He reports occasional early satiety but denies vomiting or melena. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Initial laboratory tests reveal no significant abnormalities. He has not initiated any empirical therapy.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: 4-week trial of a proton pump inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study evaluates esophageal anatomy and motility, useful for dysphagia or structural abnormalities. However, it lacks sensitivity for gastric mucosal lesions and does not allow biopsy, making it inadequate for assessing potential gastric malignancies or ulcerative conditions in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A proton pump inhibitor trial is appropriate for patients with uncomplicated dyspepsia without alarm features. This patient, however, presents with concerning signs like weight loss and early satiety, indicating the need for diagnostic evaluation through endoscopy rather than empirical therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive H. pylori testing is suitable for patients with uncomplicated dyspepsia without alarm features. However, the patient's symptoms, including weight loss and early satiety, suggest a more serious condition, such as malignancy, requiring direct visualization via endoscopy rather than noninvasive testing.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's age and alarm features, such as unintentional weight loss and early satiety, suggest a potential gastric malignancy. Urgent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is the preferred diagnostic approach as it allows direct visualization of the gastric mucosa and enables biopsy for histopathological evaluation. This procedure is crucial for identifying lesions, ulcerations, or masses indicative of cancer, facilitating prompt diagnosis and guiding further management.

Key learning point: In patients with new-onset dyspepsia and alarm features like weight loss, an urgent endoscopy is recommended to rule out serious conditions such as gastric cancer.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with six weeks of gradually worsening epigastric pain and a 4.5 kg weight loss despite normal appetite. He denies jaundice or changes in bowel habits. Examination reveals a firm, non-tender lymph node in the left supraclavicular region. Laboratory testing shows mild microcytic anemia, and a fecal occult blood test is positive.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study evaluates the esophagus and stomach structure but does not allow for mucosal visualization or biopsy. In patients with alarm features like weight loss and anemia, direct visualization and tissue sampling via endoscopy are necessary for diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including chronic epigastric pain, weight loss, microcytic anemia, and a palpable left supraclavicular lymph node (Virchow node), suggest gastric malignancy. Upper endoscopy allows direct visualization of the gastric mucosa and facilitates biopsy, which is essential for histopathological confirmation. This procedure is crucial for diagnosing gastric cancer and guiding further management and staging.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected gastric cancer with symptoms such as epigastric pain, weight loss, and Virchow node, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is the most appropriate next step to obtain a tissue diagnosis.
Image Description:

A swelling is visible at the left supraclavicular fossa.

This finding is due to enlarged lymph nodes and is typical for lymph node metastasis from gastric cancer. It can also be found in other abdominopelvic malignancies.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum carcinoembryonic antigen is used for monitoring treatment response in established cancers, not for initial diagnosis. It lacks sensitivity and specificity for detecting malignancy. Direct visualization and biopsy are needed for diagnosis in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal computed tomography is useful for staging known malignancies but does not provide mucosal visualization or biopsy. In suspected gastric cancer, endoscopy with biopsy is necessary for diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with a two-month history of progressive epigastric discomfort, early satiety, and unintended weight loss of 6 kg. He has no known comorbidities and has never undergone any major surgeries. He does not report dysphagia, chest pain, or bone pain. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals no palpable lymphadenopathy or abdominal masses. Laboratory analyses show normal serum electrolytes and normal serum liver enzymes (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
110 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Upper endoscopy: 3-cm ulcerated lesion along the lesser curvature of the stomach; histopathology confirms moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma
Which imaging study is most appropriate to assess the extent of disease prior to determining further treatment?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis without chest imaging
Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
FDG PET-CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI provides excellent soft tissue characterization but does not cover the chest, which is essential for staging gastric adenocarcinoma. CT is preferred for initial staging due to its rapid acquisition, comprehensive coverage, and ability to assess thoracic involvement, including lung and mediastinal lymph node metastases.

B) CORRECT:

A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is crucial for staging gastric adenocarcinoma. It provides detailed images of the primary tumor, assesses local invasion, and identifies regional lymphadenopathy. Additionally, it evaluates potential distant metastases, including those in the lungs and mediastinal nodes. This comprehensive imaging is essential for accurate TNM staging, guiding treatment decisions such as surgical resection or neoadjuvant therapy, and aligns with standard diagnostic protocols for gastric cancer.

Key learning point: In the staging of gastric adenocarcinoma, a CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is crucial for assessing the extent of the disease, including local invasion, lymph node involvement, and distant metastases.
Image Description:

Fluoroscopy of the stomach (with oral contrast) and CT abdomen (axial; with IV contrast)

The gastric wall is thickened and irregular (green overlay) with an abnormal narrowing.

These findings are consistent with gastric cancer with stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

FDG PET-CT scans detect metabolic activity but have limitations in gastric adenocarcinoma due to variable FDG uptake and inferior spatial resolution. They are less sensitive for small-volume disease and peritoneal carcinomatosis. Physiological FDG uptake by normal gastric tissue can obscure tumor delineation, making it suboptimal for detailed anatomical staging.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is limited in staging gastric adenocarcinoma due to its operator dependency and interference from bowel gas. It cannot adequately assess the primary tumor's extent, regional lymph nodes, or peritoneal surfaces. While useful for detecting liver lesions, it lacks the detailed cross-sectional imaging needed for comprehensive staging.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man presents with 3 months of progressive epigastric pain, reduced appetite, and an 8-kg weight loss. He reports occasional dark stools but denies vomiting. On examination, he appears pale and has a firm, non-tender enlargement in the left supraclavicular area. Vital signs are stable. Serum chemistries are within normal limits (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
100 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Stool




 Occult blood
Positive
Negative



Which condition is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colon carcinoma can present with weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, and positive occult blood in the stool. However, the patient's epigastric pain and left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy (Virchow's node) are more indicative of upper gastrointestinal tract pathology, such as gastric malignancy, rather than colon carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic adenocarcinoma often presents with weight loss and epigastric pain, but the presence of melena, anemia, and a left supraclavicular lymph node suggests an upper gastrointestinal tract origin. Pancreatic cancer typically presents with painless obstructive jaundice, especially when located in the head of the pancreas, which is absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma typically presents with progressive dysphagia due to esophageal narrowing. The patient's epigastric pain, occult bleeding, and left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy suggest a lower upper gastrointestinal tract lesion, such as gastric adenocarcinoma, rather than esophageal cancer.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including progressive epigastric pain, reduced appetite, significant weight loss, and chronic gastrointestinal bleeding (evidenced by low hemoglobin and positive stool guaiac test), are consistent with gastric adenocarcinoma. The firm, non-tender left supraclavicular lymph node, known as Virchow's node, suggests metastatic spread from a gastric primary tumor. Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common type of stomach cancer, often linked to chronic gastritis and Helicobacter pylori infection. Diagnosis is confirmed through upper endoscopy with biopsy, which provides histopathological evaluation.

Key learning point: Palpable supraclavicular lymph nodes (Virchow's nodes) and significant weight loss in the context of epigastric discomfort are indicative of stomach carcinoma.
Image Description:

A swelling is visible at the left supraclavicular fossa.

This finding is due to enlarged lymph nodes and is typical for lymph node metastasis from gastric cancer. It can also be found in other abdominopelvic malignancies.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety. He reports a 9.4-kg weight loss over the past 4 months. He immigrated from Taiwan 10 years ago. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals an ulcerated mass with raised irregular edges in the body of the stomach at the lesser curvature. Biopsy of the mass confirms gastric adenocarcinoma. Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low-fiber diet is a significant risk factor for colorectal cancers, but it is only a minor risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. A different dietary factor is a much more significant contributor to the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAID use is associated with an overall decreased, not increased, risk of intestinal-type gastric cancer. NSAIDs are thought to have an inhibitory effect on carcinogenesis because of their antiproliferative and antiinflammatory action.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is not associated with gastric adenocarcinoma. IBD is an important risk factor for colorectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Studies have shown that individuals with blood type A are at increased risk for both gastric cancer and Helicobacter pylori infection. However, no significant association between blood type O and gastric cancer has been demonstrated.

E) CORRECT:

Dietary nitrates are converted to nitrites by oral commensals, and if the diet is low in antioxidants, these nitrites can be converted in the acidic, protein-rich environment of the stomach to nitrosamine compounds (e.g., dimethylnitrosamine), most of which are highly carcinogenic. Green leafy vegetables, which contain high levels of nitrates as well as antioxidants, do not increase the risk of gastric cancer. However, increased consumption of smoked, dried, fried, and preserved foods (especially meat), which contain low levels of antioxidants and high levels of nitrates, nitrites, and nitrosamines, is a significant risk factor for the development of gastric adenocarcinoma. Smoked food is a common part of the diet in East Asia, and individuals from this region have an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Other important risk factors for localized gastric adenocarcinoma include tobacco smoking, alcohol consumption, obesity, and infection with Helicobacter pylori.

Key learning point: Dietary exposure to nitrosamines, commonly found in smoked and preserved foods, is a major risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma, especially in regions such as East Asia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with black, tarry stools for 2 days and lightheadedness. He reports a 25-lb weight loss over 3 months. Vital signs are BP, 90/60; P, 110. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae, a palpable firm epigastric mass, and melena on rectal examination. Hemoglobin is 6.3 g/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: IV access and blood type and crossmatch

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding evidenced by melena and severe anemia with hemodynamic instability (hypotension and tachycardia). The palpable epigastric mass and weight loss suggest gastric malignancy as the bleeding source. The immediate priority is hemodynamic stabilization through adequate IV access and preparation for blood transfusion. Two large-bore IVs and blood type and crossmatch for urgent transfusion are essential first steps.

B) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are appropriate for upper GI bleeding management but are not the immediate priority in a hemodynamically unstable patient with severe anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal balloon tamponade may be used for variceal bleeding in patients with portal hypertension. This patient's presentation with an epigastric mass and weight loss suggests gastric malignancy as the bleeding source, not esophageal varices, making balloon tamponade inappropriate and potentially harmful.

D) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube placement may help assess ongoing bleeding but is not the immediate priority in hemodynamically unstable patients. Additionally, NG tube placement can be risky in patients with suspected malignant lesions due to perforation risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is used for variceal bleeding, typically in patients with known portal hypertension. This patient's presentation with an epigastric mass and weight loss suggests gastric malignancy rather than variceal bleeding as the source.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with 3 days of postprandial vomiting, early satiety, and progressive abdominal distention. He reports having lost 12 pounds in the past month. He appears dehydrated; vital signs are BP, 95/60; P, 110. Laboratory studies show hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: NPO status and IV fluid resuscitation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While upper endoscopy will likely be needed for definitive diagnosis and treatment, it is not the most appropriate initial management.

B) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is likely to be helpful for evaluating the underlying cause, but it should not take priority over immediate supportive care in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

While proton pump inhibitors are components of supportive care for gastric outlet obstruction, they do not address the patient's most pressing issues of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The clinical presentation suggests gastric outlet obstruction with characteristic postprandial vomiting, early satiety, abdominal distention, and hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Initial supportive care should prioritize establishing NPO status to prevent further vomiting and IV fluid resuscitation with electrolyte repletion to address the patient's dehydration and metabolic derangements before pursuing definitive treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

While antiemetics and parenteral nutrition are components of supportive care for gastric outlet obstruction, they are not the most appropriate initial interventions.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive epigastric pain, early satiety, and an unintentional 15-pound weight loss. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender supraclavicular lymph node. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed, and biopsies of a large gastric ulcer confirm the presence of adenocarcinoma. An increased intake of which of the following is most strongly associated with this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: Fresh fruits and leafy green vegetables

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diets high in smoked, pickled, and salt-preserved foods are a major risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. These foods contain high concentrations of nitrates and nitrites, which are converted in the acidic stomach environment to carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds. These compounds cause DNA damage in gastric epithelial cells, promoting malignant transformation. High salt intake also directly damages the gastric mucosa, leading to chronic atrophic gastritis, a well-established precursor lesion. Other critical risk factors for gastric cancer include chronic Helicobacter pylori infection, which is the single strongest risk factor, smoking, and a family history of gastric cancer. This patient's presentation with alarm symptoms (weight loss, early satiety) and a Virchow's node is classic for advanced disease.

B) INCORRECT:

A diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables is protective against gastric cancer. These foods are high in antioxidants, such as vitamin C and beta-carotene, which are thought to inhibit the formation of carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds in the stomach.

C) INCORRECT:

A high-fat, low-fiber diet is a plausible risk factor as it is strongly associated with other gastrointestinal malignancies. However, this pattern is most classically linked to colorectal cancer, not gastric adenocarcinoma. The mechanisms for colorectal cancer risk involve an altered gut microbiome, increased production of carcinogenic secondary bile acids, and prolonged colonic transit time.

D) INCORRECT:

While dietary components are often evaluated for cancer risk, high intake of dairy and calcium has not been established as a risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma. In fact, some evidence suggests that calcium intake may have a neutral or even a slightly protective effect against certain gastrointestinal cancers, particularly colorectal cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

High intake of refined sugars and processed carbohydrates is associated with obesity, a known risk factor for several malignancies, including adenocarcinoma of the gastric cardia and esophagus. However, for gastric adenocarcinoma overall, particularly the more common non-cardia type, the link to other dietary risk factors is a much stronger and more direct etiologic association than the one with refined sugars.
questions.hint: The patient's alarm symptoms and a Virchow's node are consistent with metastatic gastric cancer. This malignancy is strongly associated with dietary carcinogens formed from food preservatives.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of early satiety, a 15-lb unintentional weight loss, and vague epigastric discomfort. He has no significant past medical history. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor and mild, diffuse tenderness in the upper abdomen. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL with a low mean corpuscular volume. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most suggestive of metastatic disease from a gastric primary?

choices.text: Velvety, hyperpigmented plaques in the axilla
A firm, non-tender left supraclavicular lymph node
A holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tender and mobile lymph nodes are characteristic of a reactive or infectious process, such as a viral or bacterial pharyngitis. In contrast, lymph nodes containing metastatic tumor cells are typically firm, non-tender, and fixed to underlying tissues. The bilateral and tender nature of these nodes makes a metastatic origin from a gastric primary highly unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

This describes acanthosis nigricans, a dermatologic finding that can be a paraneoplastic sign of an underlying malignancy, particularly gastric adenocarcinoma. However, it is a paraneoplastic syndrome, which is a systemic effect of the cancer, rather than a direct metastasis of tumor cells to a distant site. This patient's presentation makes this finding plausible, but it does not represent metastatic spread.

C) CORRECT:

This finding describes a Virchow node, a classic physical exam sign of metastatic gastric cancer. The left supraclavicular fossa contains the terminus of the thoracic duct, which drains lymph from the abdominal cavity. Therefore, tumor cells from a gastric primary can ascend via the thoracic duct and deposit in this node, making it palpable. The node is typically firm, non-tender, and fixed. Its presence is a strong indicator of advanced, metastatic disease and a poor prognosis. Other specific metastatic signs associated with gastric cancer include a periumbilical nodule (Sister Mary Joseph nodule) and a palpable rectal shelf (Blumer shelf).

D) INCORRECT:

A new holosystolic murmur at the apex in a patient with malignancy and weight loss could raise suspicion for nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (marantic endocarditis). This is a paraneoplastic condition associated with adenocarcinomas, including gastric cancer. However, it is a relatively rare finding and is a systemic effect of the malignancy, not a direct metastasis. A more common cause would be primary mitral valve pathology unrelated to the suspected cancer.
questions.hint: The patient's alarm symptoms, including unintentional weight loss and early satiety, combined with evidence of chronic gastrointestinal bleeding (microcytic anemia), are highly concerning for a gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of worsening postprandial epigastric pain, early satiety, and non-bilious vomiting. He reports vomiting undigested food consumed 8-12 hours earlier and has lost 9 kg (20 lbs) unintentionally. His medical history is significant for osteoarthritis, for which he frequently uses ibuprofen. On examination, he appears cachectic. The abdomen is soft with mild epigastric tenderness. A succussion splash is noted on auscultation. Laboratory studies reveal a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study?

choices.text: Abdominal CT scan with oral contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placing a nasogastric tube is an important initial management step to decompress the stomach, relieve symptoms, and correct fluid and electrolyte imbalances. Aspiration of a large volume of foul-smelling fluid hours after a meal supports the diagnosis of gastric outlet obstruction. However, this is a therapeutic and supportive maneuver, not the definitive diagnostic study to determine the cause of the obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

This study measures the rate of gastric emptying and would be abnormal in this patient. However, its primary role is to diagnose functional disorders like gastroparesis, not mechanical obstruction. Since the clinical picture strongly suggests a physical blockage, this study would only confirm delayed emptying without identifying the underlying structural cause.

C) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow, or upper GI series, can demonstrate a dilated stomach and a narrowed outlet, confirming the presence of an obstruction. However, it has been largely replaced by a different test, which provides better evaluation of the gastric and duodenal mucosa and allows for further interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

An abdominal CT scan can be useful in showing a distended stomach and potentially identifying extrinsic compression from a mass, such as pancreatic cancer. However, it is not the most appropriate diagnostic study because it is less sensitive for evaluating mucosal disease of the stomach and duodenum, and does not allow for further interventions.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is classic for gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). An upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy or EGD) is the diagnostic procedure of choice. It allows for direct visualization of the gastric mucosa, pylorus, and duodenum to identify the cause of the obstruction, which is most commonly peptic ulcer disease or malignancy. Crucially, endoscopy permits biopsy of any suspicious lesions to differentiate between benign and malignant etiologies, which is essential for guiding subsequent management. It can also offer therapeutic intervention, such as balloon dilation for a benign stricture.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of symptoms (early satiety, postprandial non-bilious vomiting of old food, aweight loss), physical exam finding of a succussion splash, and classic electrolyte abnormalities suggest a mechanical blockage at the distal stomach.
